The Niger River is the main river of West Africa, extending about 4,180 kilometres. Its source is in the Guinea Highlands in south-eastern Guinea near the Sierra Leone border. It runs in a crescent shape through Mali, Niger, on the border with Benin and then through Nigeria, discharging through a massive delta, known as the Niger Delta, into the Gulf of Guinea in the Atlantic Ocean. The Niger is the third-longest river in Africa, exceeded by the Nile and the Congo River. Its main tributary is the Benue River.

1942 Easter Sunday Raid: During the Easter Sunday Raid, the Japanese bombed the RAF units at RAF Ratmalana but passed over the Racecourse Airstrip without knowing it existed, allowing the Hurricanes of No. 11 Squadron to deploy and intercept the Japanese raiders. 2012 Renovation and redevelopment: The ground was redeveloped as the Colombo Racecourse Sports Complex to become the first International Rugby Union ground in Sri Lanka to host all the national rugby union side's home matches. 2014 Major renovation: The ground underwent a major renovation, which included the installation of floodlights and the conversion of a substantial part of the grandstand into a shopping and dining complex.

Trentham Estate has a rich history dating back to the Domesday Book in 1086. It was originally a royal manor and later housed an Augustinian priory. The estate underwent numerous transformations under the ownership of the Leveson-Gower family, including the construction of several grand houses. The most notable architectural contributions were made by Charles Barry in the 19th century. The estate served as the Staffordshire seat of the Dukes of Sutherland until the hall was abandoned in 1905 and later demolished in 1912-13. The estate has since been restored and is now a popular visitor attraction.

Rani Ki Vav is an example of Maru-Gurjara architecture, featuring seven levels of stairs leading to a deep circular well. The stepwell is adorned with over 500 principal sculptures and more than a thousand minor ones, depicting Hindu deities, celestial beings, and everyday life scenes. The structure includes 212 pillars, intricate carvings, and ornamental designs.

Wat Yai Chai Mongkhon is a Buddhist temple in Ayutthaya, Thailand. The monastery was constructed by King U-Thong in 1357 AD to accommodate the monks that were ordained by Phra Wanratana Mahathera Burean. This monastery was named "Wat Pakaew". Later, King Naresuan the Great constructed a large Chedi in 1592 AD as a memorial for his victory over Maha Uparacha of Burma. The monastery became known as Wat Yai Chaimongkhon.

Cái Răng Floating Market is a wholesale floating market specializing in the trade of vegetables and fruits on the Hau River. It developed because waterways played a near-exclusive role in transportation. As trade demand increased, people gathered at river junctions, making them ideal spots for trading. Today, although the road network has expanded significantly, leading to the disappearance of many floating markets, tourism activities have allowed Cái Răng Floating Market to evolve into a more sustainable form.

The station is connected to the Fil bleu urban transport network, including line A of the Tours tramway and various bus lines. In 2018, the station's annual usage was estimated at 4,690,784 passengers, rising to 5,863,480 if non-passengers are included.

The Srinagarind Dam is an embankment dam on the Khwae Yai River in Si Sawat District of Kanchanaburi Province, Thailand. It was named after Princess Srinagarindra. Feasibility studies were carried out between May 1967 and May 1969, and designs were completed from September 1970 to December 1977. Construction began in 1974 and was completed in 1980. The first generator was commissioned in 1980 and the last in 1991. The original cost was estimated at US$45 million but increased to US$114 million due to reinforcement required for the fault line foundation.

The well has a narrow opening, just wide enough to allow the body of a man to pass through with arms uplifted, and this narrow neck, which is about 4 ft. long, opens into the well itself, which is cylindrically shaped, and opens about 7 ft. 6 in. in diameter. The well and upper part of the well are built of masonry, and the well appears to have been sunk through a mixture of alluvial soil and limestone fragments, till a compact bed of mountain limestone was reached, having horizontal strata which could be easily worked; and the interior of the well presents the appearance of having been lined throughout with rough masonry.

The Royal Palace of La Granja de San Ildefonso, known as La Granja, is an early 18th-century palace in the small town of San Ildefonso, located in the hills near Segovia and 80 kilometres (50 mi) north of Madrid, within the Province of Segovia in central Spain. It became the summer residence of the kings of Spain from the 1720s during the reign of King Philip V. The palace is in a restrained Baroque style, surrounded by extensive gardens in the formal Jardin à la française style with sculptural fountains. It is now open to the public as a museum.

The Cardamom Mountains are culturally significant due to their unique jar burials, rock art, and role in Khmer history. The jar burials, containing ceramic jars and log coffins, represent a previously unrecorded burial practice in Khmer culture. The rock art in Kanam Cave depicts ancient elephants, deer, and wild cows, reflecting the region's ecological and cultural history.

Tangkuban Perahu is a stratovolcano in West Java, Indonesia. It is a remnant of the ancient Mount Sunda after the plinian eruption caused the Caldera to collapse. The name translates roughly to 'upturning of (a) boat' or 'upturned boat' in Sundanese, referring to the local legend of its creation involving Dayang Sumbi and Sangkuriang.

The tombs are sited according to Feng Shui principles, with an arc-shaped valley area at the foot of the Jundu Mountains. A 7-kilometer road named the 'Spirit Way' leads into the complex, lined with statues of guardian animals and officials. The front gate consists of a three-arches, painted red, and called the 'Great Red Gate'. The Spirit Way starts with a huge stone memorial archway, one of the biggest stone archways in China today. Further in, there is a 50-ton stone statue of a Bixi carrying a memorial tablet, and four white marble Huabiao (pillars of glory) are positioned at each corner of the stele pavilion. The road leads to 18 pairs of stone statues of mythical animals, leading to a three-arched gate known as the Dragon and Phoenix Gate.

Falkland Palace, in Falkland, Fife, Scotland, is a royal palace of the Scottish kings. It was one of the favourite places of Mary, Queen of Scots, who took refuge there from political and religious turmoil of her times. Today it is under the stewardship of Ninian Stuart, who delegates most of his duties to the National Trust for Scotland. The Chapel Royal in the Palace is dedicated to Thomas the Apostle. It is open to the public and reserved for Catholic worship. In the late 12th century, a royal hunting lodge was located on this site. The lodge was expanded in the 13th century to operate as a castle, owned by the Earls of Fife of the noted Clan MacDuff. The castle was built here because the site is on a slight hill that could be defended. The surrounding land eventually were developed as the Palace gardens.

Tarawera Falls is a 65 m high waterfall on the Tarawera River in the Bay of Plenty region in New Zealand's North Island. The Tarawera River flows out of Lake Tarawera and across a rhyolitic lava flow that erupted from Mt Tarawera about 14,000 years ago. The river disappears about 30 metres back from the clifftop into flooded caves in the lava and pours out halfway up the cliff on the far side of the flow. The falls were formed where the 14,009 ± 155 BP Pokohu lava flow from the Waiohau eruption of Mount Tarawera covered earlier tephra deposits. The major contributor to today's amphitheatre was likely to be the large flood that followed the lake outlet damming by events associated with the 5526 ± 145 BP Whakatane eruption.

The Ziggurat of Ur is a Neo-Sumerian ziggurat built during the Early Bronze Age (21st century BC) in the city of Ur near Nasiriyah, Iraq. It was dedicated to the moon god Nanna, the patron deity of Ur. The structure crumbled to ruins by the 6th century BC and was restored by King Nabonidus. It was excavated in the 1920s and 1930s by Sir Leonard Woolley and partially reconstructed under Saddam Hussein in the 1980s.

His Majesty's Prisons (Her Majesty's Prisons in the case of a female monarch) is the name given to prisons in the United Kingdom, as well as some in Australia and a small number in Canada, Grenada, Jersey, The Bahamas and Barbados. The title makes up part of the name of individual prisons and is usually abbreviated to HM Prison or HMP. The title of HM Prison is given to a number of prisons in Australia, especially in the state of Victoria. Fox Hill Prison in Nassau was formerly known as Her Majesty's Prisons. The title of HM Prison was given to HMP Dodds Prison in St. Philip, until the crown was dissolved, it was also the name given to the former Glendairy Prison in Station Hill, St. Michael. The Belize Museum was formerly a HM prison. Her Majesty's Penitentiary (as of September 2023 the name has not changed to reflect the accession of King Charles III) at 89 Forest Road in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador was built in 1859, and is still operational as a men's correctional facility of the Department of Justice and Public Safety of Newfoundland and Labrador. In November 2021, the government of Newfoundland and Labrador issued a request for proposals to design, build and finance a new prison to replace the aging HMP facility. The title of His Majesty's Prison (Grenada) is given to the Richmond Hill Prison in Saint George's, Grenada. The prison is run by the Ministry of National Security. The prison governor is Dr John Mitchell, the Commissioner of Prisons in Grenada. The prison accommodates both sexes, but has separate sections for male and female prisoners. As of 2019 it held 463 prisoners, more than double its official capacity of 198.

The main lhakhang (chapel) has a large image of the Sakyamuni (Buddha), with images of eight bodhisattvas on both sides. Originally founded in the 17th century as a ksar (fortified village), it was expanded in the 19th century into a kasbah by M'hamed Ben Brahim Nasiri, a local privileged family member. It is considered one of the most impressive kasbahs in Morocco and was featured on the Moroccan 50 dirham note.

The Talatal Ghar is an 18th-century palace and military base located in Rangpur, Assam, India. It is the largest monument built during the Ahom era. Initially constructed by King Rudra Singha with semi-permanent materials, it was later rebuilt with major additions in bricks by King Rajeswar Singha. The palace originally had seven storeys, with three underground floors and two secret tunnels. It served as an army base and had royal apartments on the upper floors. Over time, the structure has deteriorated, and the underground floors were sealed during the British era.

St Mary's Abbey, Melrose is a partly ruined monastery of the Cistercian order in Melrose, Roxburghshire, in the Scottish Borders. It was founded in 1136 by Cistercian monks at the request of King David I of Scotland and was the chief house of that order in the country until the Reformation. The abbey is known for its many carved decorative details, including likenesses of saints, dragons, gargoyles, and plants. It was rebuilt after several attacks and is now maintained by Historic Environment Scotland as a scheduled monument.

The Castle of Jagua is a fortress located south of Cienfuegos in Cuba, near the entrance to the Cienfuegos Bay. It was originally named 'Castillo de Nuestra Señora de los Ángeles de Jagua' and was built in 1742 by King Philip V of Spain to protect the bay from pirates. The fortress played a crucial role in safeguarding the bay and the city of Cienfuegos, which was founded in 1819. The fort is built in solid limestone and features several floors, a well, a watch tower, and a moat with a drawbridge that remains in perfect condition.

The Fairmont Le Château Frontenac, commonly referred to as the Château Frontenac, is a historic hotel in Quebec City, Quebec, Canada. The hotel is situated in Old Quebec, within the historic district's Upper Town, on the southern side of Place d'Armes. The Château Frontenac was designed by Bruce Price, and was built by the Canadian Pacific Railway company. The hotel is managed by Fairmont Hotels and Resorts. Opened in 1893, the Châteauesque-styled building has 18 floors; its 79.9-metre (262-foot) height is augmented by its 54-metre (177-foot) ground elevation. It is one of the first completed grand railway hotels, and was designated a National Historic Site of Canada in 1981. The hotel was expanded on three occasions, with the last major expansion taking place in 1993.

The building underwent significant expansions and renovations over the centuries, including during the Spanish Civil War when it was used as a concentration camp. Today, it operates as a luxury parador hotel, church, and museum.

The Suzdal Kremlin is the oldest part of the city of Suzdal, Russia, dating from the 10th century. It was originally a fortress or citadel which was the religious and administrative center of the city. It is most notably the site of the Cathedral of the Nativity. Together with several structures in the neighboring city of Vladimir, it was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1992. The fortress was strategically located on a bend of the Kamenka river on three sides and a moat to the east. It was surrounded by earthen ramparts that remain to the present day. A settlement to the east became home to the secular population - shopkeepers and craftsmen, while the Kremlin proper was the home of the prince, the archbishop, and the high clergy. From the 13th to the 16th centuries, several monasteries and churches were constructed, including the Cathedral of the Nativity, the Intercession Convent, and the Monastery of Our Saviour and St. Euthymius.

Excavation started on the right bank of the river, but the idea was abandoned because the dolomite was too hard and the work was too slow and difficult. 19th century Russian canal plans: Russia had plans to create a network of canals to unite all the seas of its European part. The idea was to create waterways between the Baltic Sea and the Black Sea across the Venta, Neman and Dnieper rivers. Turkish prisoners of war were commandeered to build a canal, but the dolomite bedrock was too hard to dig and the river was not wide and deep enough for shipping. Construction was discontinued in 1831, but the canal was dug around the waterfall 30 years later. 1977 Designation as a natural monument: The Venta Rapid was designated a natural monument of Latvia.

Poulnabrone dolmen is a large dolmen located in the Burren, County Clare, Ireland. It dates to the early Neolithic period, with estimates from 3800 and 3200 BC. It was constructed on a unique karst landscape formed from limestone laid down around 350 million years ago. The dolmen was built by Neolithic farmers, who chose the location either for ritual, as a territorial marker, or as a collective burial site. When the site was excavated in 1986 and again in 1988, around 33 human remains, including those of adults and children, were found buried underneath it.

The volcano is considered 'pristine' due to no influence from other volcanoes on its growth, and its cone is highly symmetrical. Its growth occurs in phases based on weaknesses of the crust it rests on, causing shifts and further volcanic growth.

The fortress was damaged by the 1461 L'Aquila earthquake and was not rebuilt.

Castle of the Pomeranian Dukes - the only Gothic castle located on the coast of the Baltic Sea in Poland. The castle's construction began in 1352, in the reign of Bogusław V, whose reign began the alliance with the Hanseatic League. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries the castle was used as a warehouse and a prison. In 1930, the castle was turned into a museum. The castle was enlarged and modernised in the fifteenth and sixteenth century, becoming a worthy royal residence. The greatest expansion of the castle was done under the reign of Eric of Pomerania, who rebuilt the castle to that of the design of his previous residence, Kronborg Castle. He also modernised the castle's defensive fortifications, and built a second defence line, in the form of dikes around the castle. The following expansion of the castle was done under the reign of Duke Bogusław X, when a new wing was built. The next changes were done by Duke Barnim XI. After a great fire, which devastated the castle in 1624, the last Duke of the House of Pomerania, Bogusław XIV, rebuilt the castle. However, he did not restore the castle to its original architectural style. The castle lost many of its defences, and a chapel was built inside the Duke Hall. After the duke's death, his widow, Duchess Elżbieta, took over the castle, and lived there until her death.

The Rock of Cashel, also known as Cashel of the Kings and St. Patrick's Rock, is a historical site located dramatically above a plain at Cashel, County Tipperary, Ireland. According to local legends, the Rock of Cashel originated in the Devil's Bit, a mountain 20 miles north of Cashel when St. Patrick banished Satan from a cave, resulting in the Rock's landing in Cashel. The Rock of Cashel was the traditional seat of the kings of Munster as early as the 4th century and prior to the Norman invasion. In the 5th century, the Eóganachta clan built a fortress at Cashel retaining supremacy there for hundreds of years. In 977, Brian Boru was crowned there as king and made Cashel his capital. In 1101, the King of Munster, Muirchertach Ua Briain, donated his fortress on the Rock to the Church.

It was developed as part of the Misamis Occidental Aquamarine Development and Protection Program (MOADPP) launched in 2002 to convert the area into an ecotourism site, enhancing revenue generation while prioritizing environmental preservation. The park includes facilities such as hotels, cottages, a mini zoo, function halls, restaurants, incubators, and a mangrove reforestation area. The Marshall County Courthouse was completed in 1886 to replace an earlier building. It is the third building used for county business. Initially, county business was conducted in officials' homes, followed by a frame structure in Marietta and later a brick building in Marshalltown. The current courthouse was built after voters approved a $100,000 budget. It was designed by John C. Cochrane and constructed using native limestone over brick. The courthouse underwent significant renovations in the 1970s after years of deterioration and was damaged by a tornado in 2018, requiring extensive repairs.

The monument consists of a decorative arch, an auditorium that can accommodate around 3,500 people, and the Kural Manimandapa, where all the 1,330 couplets from all 133 chapters of the Kural literature are inscribed on bas-relief. The hallmark of the monument is the 39-meter-high (128-foot) stone car, a replica of the famed temple chariot of Thiruvarur. The chariot is made of around 3000 blocks of granite stone from Tiruvannamalai and weighs 2,700 tonnes. The four giant-sized wheels of the chariot measure 11 feet in diameter and 2 feet in thickness. A life-size statue of Valluvar has been installed in the chariot, which is adorned with Kalamkari drawings. The bottom portion of the chariot features bas relief sculptures depicting all the 133 chapters of the Kural text. The central auditorium measures 220 feet by 100 feet and is said to be Asia's largest at the time of its construction. The roof of the monument has a terraced garden with two large pools.

Al Shouf Cedar Nature Reserve is the largest natural reserve in Lebanon, covering 5.3% of the country's territory. The reserve is an Important Bird Area (IBA) and Eco-tourism area, hosting 32 species of wild mammals, 200 species of birds, and 500 species of plants. The Barouk mountain comprises limestone rocks from the Pliocene, with significant tectonic activity dividing the mountains of Lebanon into the Anti-Lebanon and Mount Lebanon ranges. The reserve is also known for its efforts to conserve the cedar of Lebanon and its rich biodiversity.

Doi Tung is a mountain in the Thai highlands, known for its steep rise near the Thailand-Myanmar border. It is the highest point of the Doi Nang Non, a subrange of the Daen Lao Range, in the 'Golden Triangle' area. The mountain's bedrock is mostly limestone and granite, with deciduous forest below 1,000 m and evergreen vegetation above. The population consists of various tribes, including Akha, Lahu, Tai Lue, and Lawa. The area has a significant Buddhist temple, Wat Phra That Doi Tung, dating back to 911. The Doi Tung Development Project has significantly improved the local economy, and the Doi Tung Royal Villa, former residence of Princess Mother Srinagarindra, now serves as a museum.

Hooiberg is a distinctively shaped, 165 m (541 ft) conical hill located at the heart of the island of Aruba. It has long been a prominent and recognizable landmark. Historically known as Orcuyo, it has had various names such as Cerro de Paja ó Pan de Azucar in Spanish, meaning 'hill of straw' or 'sugarloaf'. The Dutch named it Hooiberg, meaning 'haystack', due to its resemblance to a loose haystack. It is a Cretaceous-era tonalitic batholith and has been used as an orientation point and watchtower by indigenous peoples. In modern times, it has hosted radio and television masts and a navigation light.

The Mississippi State Capitol, also known as the 'New Capitol,' has been the seat of the state’s government since 1903. It succeeded the old Mississippi State House and was designated as a Mississippi Landmark in 1986, a National Historic Landmark in 2016, and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1969. The construction was initiated by Governor Andrew Houston Longino, and the design was selected through an architectural contest, with Theodore C. Link as the architect and Bernard R. Green as the consultant. The Capitol was completed in 1903, funded by a legal settlement with the Illinois Central Railroad. It originally housed all three branches of government but now primarily serves the Legislative branch.

Montrose Basin is a nearly circular tidal basin part of the estuary of the River South Esk. It has been designated as a Wildlife Reserve, Local Nature Reserve, Site of Special Scientific Interest, Special Protection Area, and Ramsar Site. The basin has a variety of habitats including tidal mudflats, saltmarsh, reedbed, and fen. It has been a site for studying sea level fluctuations post the last glaciation and contains the largest area of saltmarsh in Angus. The basin has a rich biodiversity including large populations of invertebrates and over 213 species of birds. It has a history of human activity dating back to over 3,000 BCE and was exploited for seafood, especially Atlantic salmon and mussels. The basin was hit by a tsunami in 6,100 BCE due to the Storegga Slide in Norway.

The Minato Bridge is a double-deck cantilever truss bridge in Osaka, Japan. Ignacio Agramonte International Airport is an international airport in central Camagüey Province, Cuba. It serves the city of Camagüey and the resort village of Santa Lucía. During World War II, the airport was used by the United States Army Air Forces Sixth Air Force from 1942 until 1944. The 25th Bombardment Group 417th Bombardment Squadron flew B-18 Bolo bombers from the airfield, known as Camaguey Air Base, from 13 April 1942 though August 1943. The squadron flew antisubmarine missions over the northern Caribbean. The base was also used for air-sea rescue missions by the 1st Rescue Squadron. From 1 January 1943, the USAAF set up postal operations for Camaguey using Army Post Office, Miami with the address: 2714 APO MIA. The United States Navy also set up to use a non-descript number for postal operations. They used the Fleet Post Office, Atlantic located in New York City with the address: 617 FPO NY. The airport also used to be a base for the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces with the 3685th Regiment and 2 General purpose transport squadron operating Mil Mi-17 helicopters based here. The airport was closed from March to October 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

A second quadrangle, Polk Place, was built in the 1920s to the south of the original campus, with the South Building on its north side, and named after North Carolina native and university alumnus President James K. Polk. The Wilson Library is at the south end of Polk Place.

The Sendai Mediatheque features a steel-ribbed structure with partial reinforced concrete. It consists of three main elements: tubes, plates, and skin. The tubes, made of thick-walled steel pipes, serve as structural supports and house vertical circulation for air, water, electricity, light, and people. The plates (floor slabs) are composed of a honeycomb-like network of steel sections infilled with lightweight concrete. The skin (facade) is made of glass, steel panels, and aluminum mesh, modulating light and views. The building's design blurs boundaries between traditional library and museum typologies, encouraging flexibility of use.

Jackson Hole Airport (IATA: JAC, ICAO: KJAC, FAA LID: JAC) is the busiest airport in Wyoming by passenger traffic. During peak summer and winter seasons, it offers nonstop airline service from up to 15 destinations across the United States. The airport is served year-round by Alaska Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Airlines and seasonally by Sun Country Airlines. The airport is noise sensitive and bans older, noisier aircraft with stage-II engines. The airport currently has eleven hard stand gates and three baggage carousels. Jackson Hole Airport does not have jet bridges so passengers board aircraft via ramps. The airport terminal has a restaurant and gift shop post security as well as a cafe by the baggage claim area. The airport is served by Alamo, Avis, Budget, Enterprise and National rental car companies. Dollar, Hertz, and Thrifty offer shuttle service from the airport to in-town rental cars. Jackson Hole Airport is one of 16 airports that employs its security screeners under contract with the Transportation Security Administration's Screening Partnership Program. The airport has an antler arch at the entrance to terminal from the taxiway similar to the one in the town square.

Hinulugang Taktak Protected Landscape, also known as Hinulugan Taktak, is a protected area in Rizal, Philippines. Initially assigned as a recreation area, the waterfall area has been designated as a national park by virtue of Republic Act No. 6964 in 1990. Ten years later, it became a protected landscape under Proclamation No. 412. It is managed by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources and the Rizal Provincial Government. Folk knowledge has it that the name was derived from a large bell (taktak) that was thrown (hinulog) into the falls during the 15th century or the 16th century because the local villagers considered it too loud. Since then, it has become known as Hinulugang Taktak or the place where the bell fell.

The Mambilla Plateau is the highest plateau in Nigeria, with an average elevation of about 1,600 metres (5,249 ft) above sea level. It is located in the southeastern part of Taraba State and is bounded by an escarpment that is about 900 m (2,953 ft) high in some places. The plateau is hilly with deep gorges and is dissected by many streams, notably the Donga River and Taraba River. The Mambilla Hydroelectric Power Station is proposed for construction in Western Mambilla near the Nigeria-Cameroon border, with an anticipated completion date of 2030. The plateau is also home to Nigeria's largest game reserve, the Gashaka/Gumti Game Reserve.

The cathedral consists of a domed sanctuary, much like an Iranian mosque, but with the significant addition of a semi-octagonal apse and raised chancel usually seen in Western-style churches. The exteriors are in relatively modern brickwork and are exceptionally plain compared to its elaborately decorated interior. The interior is covered with fine frescos and gilded carvings and includes a wainscot of rich tile work. The delicately blue and gold painted central dome depicts the Biblical story of the creation of the world and man's expulsion from Eden. Pendentives throughout the church are painted with a motif of a cherub's head surrounded by folded wings, typical of Armenian art. The ceiling above the entrance is painted with delicate floral motifs in the style of Persian miniature. Two sections, or bands, of murals run around the interior walls: the top section depicts events from the life of Jesus, while the bottom section depicts tortures inflicted upon Armenian martyrs by the Ottoman Turks.

Edgbaston Cricket Ground, located in the Edgbaston area of Birmingham, England, was established in 1882. It is home to Warwickshire County Cricket Club and its T20 team Birmingham Bears. The ground has hosted numerous Test matches, One-Day Internationals, and Twenty20 Internationals. It was the first English ground outside Lord's to host a major international one-day tournament final and has been a venue for major tournaments like the ICC Cricket World Cup 2019 and the ICC Champions Trophy 2017. The land was originally owned by the Calthorpe Estate, who developed it into an exclusive Birmingham suburb. The club initially considered other locations but chose Edgbaston due to its proximity to Birmingham's large population and railway connections.

The Rigi, also known as Mount Rigi or Queen of the Mountains, is a mountain massif of the Alps located in Central Switzerland. It is almost entirely surrounded by Lake Lucerne, Lake Zug, and Lake Lauerz. The name Rigi originates from Swiss Old High German *rigî, meaning 'horizontal stratification, strip, band'. The name was first recorded in 1350 as Riginun. The mountain has been a popular destination for centuries, with the Rigi Kulm Hotel established in 1816. The area is served by Europe's oldest mountain railways, the Rigi Railways.

Higher elevation areas are dominated by European beech and silver birch, downy birch, European aspen and sometimes by conifers Abies alba, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, Pinus nigra. The Tefé National Forest is divided between the municipalities of Tefé (46.27%), Juruá (11.89%), Carauari (4.96%) and Alvarães (36.88%) in Amazonas. It is bounded by the Tefé River to the east, the Bauana River to the north, the Andirá River to the west, and the Curumitá de Baixo River to the south. The forest is administered by the Chico Mendes Institute for Biodiversity Conservation. As of 2006, there were 359 families with an estimated total of 2,154 people in the forest, living in 30 communities along the three main rivers. The residents are mainly engaged in family farming, cultivating small fields of cassava to make flour, artisan fishing, and extraction of nuts, açaí, andiroba, copaiba, and wood.

The Central Anatolian deciduous forests, also known as the Central Anatolian woodlands and steppe, is a Palearctic ecoregion of the Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest biome. It is located in Central Anatolia, Asian Turkey. The ecoregion occupies the plateau of Central Anatolia. Belts of forested mountains surround the ecoregion, with the Mediterranean-climate Anatolian conifer and deciduous mixed forests and Southern Anatolian montane conifer and deciduous forests ecoregions in western and southern mountains, and the more temperate-climate Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests in the ranges to the north.
